embeds.title: Somber Shield
embeds.description:
Common Skill / 1 :energy_collector: / The Collector / Downfall

**Pyre.**
Gain 6 (9) **Block** :p_block:.
Next turn, gain a copy of the **Exhaust**ed card.

messages.content: I love goodstuff
Baby retain card that also works on both collectibles and activating kindlings
also activates any exhaust synergy.
it's a fine block card with a solid card manipulating effect
nice

I like Somber Shield - it's not only nice on Embers and Kindlings (as stated above), but also for setup. Eg pyre a strong attack on a turn where Nemesis is intangible. A minor downside compared to other exhaust/pyre cards is that it's not very good for getting rid of statuses and curses.
I think of it less as exhaust and more as retain with exhaust synergies
remember when people thought this would be a meta card
then it was moved to uncommon and everyone hated it
it really isn't that good honestly
it's just a good ish card
it is meta in the same way shrug is meta
moving it to uncommon is like moving shrug to uncommon
footwork is a good card so it should be rare
I think on a balanced collector it would be an extremely above average card.

>on a balanced collector
a man can dream
I think eventually it will get there, most characters take a while to get balanced
Watcher has taken 4 years and still isn't
honestly it really is just alternate shrug it off
lots of characters have the 1 cost common nice to have block card
silent has backflip
watcher has third eye?
slime boss and packmaster have reformation/sideboard (functionally equivalent, which is why I mentioned them at the same time)
hermit has coalescence
guardian has recover
hexa has The Card That Should Not Be Named
Auto has safeguard
[[sideboard]]

Common Skill / 1 :PackmasterEnergy: / The Packmaster / Pack: Core Set

Gain 8 (11) **Block** :p_block:.
Put a card from your discard pile on top of your draw pile.

messages.content: <reformation>

embeds.title: Reformation
embeds.description:
Common Skill / 1 :energy_slime: / The Slime Boss / Downfall

Gain 8 (11) **Block** :p_block:.
Put a card from your discard pile on top of the draw pile.

messages.content: i like <coalescense> more

embeds.title: Coalescence
embeds.description:
Common Skill / 1 :energy_hermit:  / The Hermit / Downfall

Gain 6 (9) **Block** :p_block:.
**Retain** up to 2 (3) cards this turn.

messages.content: ok that works
What was it originally?
vantage
Coalescence is imo just too low block for me to take it unupgraded, especially earlygame since you often don't have as much card draw that you would need retain
even I was doubtful about vantage
carbon would've definitely ripped into me about vantage
I mean, I'd say dive for me but I think more people would disagree
~~and carbon would rip into you~~
That he shall do, I will continue to take dive even if it isn't the right play
This is a solid block card that I take a fair amount of the time, though it's outshone by a number of others (It Matters Not, Double Trouble, Bonfire, Billow, Stash Away, maybe Void Armor).

It used to have very strong synergy with <Shooting Star> when that wasn't limited to attacks, thanks to Collector's expensive and powerful powers and skills. 1 energy for 6 (9) block, a free DLF/YAM/Finger of Doom/etc. this turn, and a regular copy of it the next turn (which you might also Somber Shield) was incredibly powerful.

embeds.title: Shooting Star
embeds.description:
Rare Power / 3 (2) :energy_collector: / The Collector / Downfall

The first time you **Pyre** an Attack each turn, gain a copy of it.
It costs 0 until played.

messages.content:
An interesting block card, very useful for getting more out of kindlings, triggering exhaust synergies multiple times, and "retaining" cards for a turn to line up combos or just save a block/attack/power for next turn. It can even save a collected card for the next turn with it's retain mode. One thing I would generally not recommend doing is combining this with embers or sunbloom kindling, as that often leads to hand clog issues, though if your deck had enough other pyre cards or mass exhaust cards it could be reasonable. Also loses out compared to the other pyre cards when you think about removing strikes/defends/curses/statuses from the draw pile to give yourself a better reshuffle.

The block is a little low when compared to other sources, so you want to make sure you can take advantage of the utility aspect before taking this. It's not that hard to have a deck with some cards it might want to retain for next turn, but having a few quality kindlings makes it much more viable. It's very strong with dead branch (an insanely strong relic in any collector run) as a way to generate more cards over multiple turns. This used to have several really powerful synergies (shooting star, sentries) but most of that has been patched out. Goes well with can't touch this to boost up the block, and to make defends/any blocks you might retain over better as well. Quite weak in act 1 as a defensive skill, but the retain utility gets better and better as the run goes on, so sometimes I will take this late in the run to add more mitigation and utility.

I guess I've talked myself down on this card. Not being able to pyre out basics/curses/statuses is kind of a big deal, and the numbers are low enough for it to be too close to drawing a defend. It lost some key synergies that made it particularly strong earlier in it's life, and can create issues with hand clog. Are there any really impressive combos left for this card, or is it mostly in an awkward utility space like coalescence?
but even if youre exhausting a strike or defend youre still getting the benefit of retaining that card until next turn

True, but strikes/defends are just not very good cards to retain. I think that most of the other pyre cards are better because they can trim your deck down and tend to have better raw stats, though I do appreciate the utility and consistency somber shield can offer.
